Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Students who perform poorly in mathematics early in school are at risk for continuing to struggle in mathematics throughout elementary school and beyond. Recent empirical studies of targeted interventions for students at-risk in mathematics indicate overall effectiveness at positively impacting student outcomes. However, a subset of students fail to exhibit a positive response to generally efficacious intervention programs. To date limited research has investigated the behavioral, cognitive, and neural mechanisms underlying non-response to such mathematics interventions.

The goal of this project is to identify patterns of performance on critical mathematics constructs, their underlying neural signatures, and achievement outcomes for on-track learners, at-risk controls, responders, and non-responders within the context of a random control trial of a research validated first grade math intervention. Functional magnetic resonance imaging will be utilized to explore patterns of imaging-based measures in concert with behavioral measures to facilitate an in depth exploration of critical early math processes and the behavioral and neural indicators thereof. Findings from the work will be utilized to generate hypotheses on critical math constructs as potential targets for supplemental intervention components to improve intervention outcomes for non-responders. Coupling neuroimaging and intervention research in an early mathematics context represents a unique contribution to the field, as it has not previously been attempted.

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

 Project MAP was a 1-year project aimed at demonstrating proof of concept to identify neural, domain general cognitive, and domain specific early number processes associated with mathematics achievement for first grade students. The primary aims of the project were to identify patterns of performance on critical mathematics constructs, their underlying neural signatures, and mathematics achievement outcomes for on-track learners, at-risk controls, responders, and non-responders within the context of a random control trial of a research validated math intervention, and to use these findings to generate hypotheses on critical math constructs as potential targets for supplemental intervention components to improve intervention outcomes for non-responders. Functional magnetic resonance imaging was utilized to explore patterns of imaging-based measures of plasticity observed in concert with behavioral plasticity to facilitate an in-depth exploration of critical early math processes and the behavioral and neural indicators thereof.

During the pilot study (Year 2016-2017), we collected pre- and post-data from a total of 54 first-grade students (treatment n = 22, at-risk control n = 7,  typically achieving control n = 25) in domain-specific early number skills, domain general cognitive skills, self-regulation behaviors, student performance on proximal and distal measures of math achievement, reading measures, and neuroimaging measures. In fall 2017, we collected pre-test data from the 2017-2018 year’s first-grade student cohort. Specifically, we administered the same measurement net used with the pilot cohort to a total of 50 first-grade students (treatment n = 20, at-risk control n = 5, typically achieving control n = 25). The 2017-2018 first-grade cohort constitutes Cohort 1 of the current Project MAP grant that began in spring 2018. In summer 2018, we conducted a follow-up fMRI study with the pilot cohort as part of the carry forward. Of the 54 pilot study participants, we recruited 16 students (treatment n = 8, typically achieving control n = 8) after a year interval for follow-up. Participants were re-scanned and assessed on domain general- and specific measures, a self-regulation measure, and a reading measure.

Dual Regression analysis with our pilot data (n = 51) showed significantly altered connectivity adjacent to the intraparietal sulcus associated with the ASPENS math measure. Our result suggests that the intraparietal sulcus, which has previously been linked to math achievement, shows different patterns of connectivity depending on math performance as measured by the ASPENS. Results also depicted increased connectivity in left parietal lobe, in a brain area frequently engaged in math-related tasks, for under-performing learners compared to on-track learners. These results may provide insights into how students represent math in the brain and ways we can both measure and target improvement.

We disseminated the pilot results to the communities of interest through presentations at peer-reviewed professional conferences. Specifically, we presented two posters with our pilot results at the Flux Society meeting of developmental neuroimaging and a paper at the International Mind, Brain, and Education Society conference.

 

Intellectual merit of proposed activity

            Project MAP is unique in its proposal to examine resting state connectivity to explore math achievement in whole-brain analyses. Using a data-driven approach to examining functional networks (i.e., ICA) and using rigorous pre-processing techniques from the resting state MRI literature will provide novel insights on the brain networks involved in math achievement and advance a new whole-brain theory that highlights the roles of previously implicated structures like the intraparietal sulcus and prefrontal cortex. The proposed activities will also generate new evidence on the overlap in symbolic and non-symbolic processing across groups, providing independent contributions to whole-brain connectivity differences between responders and non-responders to math interventions. Project MAP will advance knowledge regarding participation gaps in STEM fields by identifying key domain specific and domain general skills associated with neural plasticity linked to math intervention response and will inform efforts to reduce disability-related difficulties in math.

 

Broader impacts of proposed activity

            Project MAP proposes an exploration of math achievement that merges the fields of math education, special education, and cognitive neuroscience through the integration of neuroimaging into randomized control trials evaluating the efficacy of promising intervention practices. Thoughtful integration across these related fields can lead to greater insights into why some learners struggle to acquire math knowledge than would be achieved through explorations conducted in isolation. Insights gained may have a broad impact in the field as additional research questions and hypothesis are raised and investigated by researchers from a range of disciplines. In addition, because the work is one of the first investigations integrating neuroimaging into a RCT, there is potential to demonstrate a replicable design process that could guide future efforts. Finally, gaining insight into the learning needs of the non-responder population offers the opportunity to refine and expand the tools, materials, and services educators utilize to ensure all learners have full access to the field of math and to related STEM fields as they advance in their schooling.
